If You can let me know the name of the books for
testing the webapplication developed in JavaScript, it
will be great.
--- "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@...> wrote:

> Harbir Singh Hundal wrote:
> 
> > I am testing a web-application's functionallity
> with
> > JUnit, and HttpUnit. This is fine.
> > Now I have to test the performance of the
> application,
> > like the time it takes to upload the browser, or
> the
> > time taken to return if a number os users, send
> the
> > request.
> > 
> > Now I know That I can Do this with the Junitperf,
> but
> > my doubt is that what do I have to test, What I
> was
> > thinking is to do the performanceTest of the test
> that
> > test the functionality, I think this will be
> right.
> > Otherwise How will I be really be able to do the
> > performance testing for time it takes to open the
> > browser.
> 
> You have no control over how long a browser takes to
> open, so what do 
> you hope to gain from testing it? All you can do is
> get information 
> without being able to change anything. If you want
> to see how long it 
> takes the browser to open, then you need to drive
> the real browser. I 
> recommend using a shell script or a Ruby program to
> open the browser. 
> because otherwise the JVM will get in the way of
> your measurement.
> 
> There are good books on testing Java applications
> for performance, and I 
> recommend reading one or two of them. It's not a
> complex topic, but 
> there are some basics you should understand before
> you go too far.
> -- 
> J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
> Diaspar Software Services
> http://www.diasparsoftware.com
> Author, JUnit Recipes: Practical Methods for
> Programmer Testing
> 


=====
Regards
Harbir singh Hundal
